name: Palindrome Linked List

similar_questions.title: Maximum Twin Sum of a Linked List

title: Palindrome Linked List
content:
Given the head of a singly linked list, return true if it is a palindrome or false otherwise.

 

Example 1:

Input: head = [1,2,2,1]
Output: true

Example 2:

Input: head = [1,2]
Output: false

 

Constraints:

  • The number of nodes in the list is in the range [1, 105].
  • 0 <= Node.val <= 9

 

Follow up: Could you do it in O(n) time and O(1) space?

discussion_posts.name: casual-coder
discussion_posts.content: I believe coming up with an O(1) space solution for this problem is not trivial, but do you guys think it can be at medium difficulty?

discussion_posts.name: tourist_111
discussion_posts.content: This must be a medium question , it\'s in no way an easy problem.

discussion_posts.name: aarushidhingra99
discussion_posts.content: Why doesn\'t simply reversing a linked list and comparing it with the original one work? Only 78/88 cases passed.

discussion_posts.name: Sumukha1496
discussion_posts.content:
May be I did something extra. But still O(N) time and O(1) space and 1ms solution in java and faster than 95.xx%.
1. Find the mid using fast pointer and slow pointer approach = O(N/2) -> O(N).
2. Reverse the first half of the list inline = O(N/2) -> O(N) time, O(1) space.
3. Compare the 2 lists. = O(N) time, O(1) space.

So overall: O(N) time and O(1) space.

discussion_posts.name: Chipanzee
discussion_posts.content: I don\'t understand why the code compiles differently from other compilers.. I have some solution, I run it on other compiler, everything works, and here is not working.. same test case lol

discussion_posts.name: deleted_user
discussion_posts.content: Great problem, but that\'s rather a medium problem, isn\'t it?

discussion_posts.name: adamstrejcovsky
discussion_posts.content: Is there a constant space solution without messing up the original list? Because after such operation your list will end up changed.

discussion_posts.name: alitz
discussion_posts.content:
It seems the system checks the linked list when judging the answer. If there is a loop in the list, there will be a Time Limit Exceed error.

For example, if you reverse the second half of the list a=>b=>c=>NULL, there will be two result:

 1. a-->b--><--c (b's next is c and c's next is b)
 2. a-->b-->NULL and c-->b-->NULL (b's next is NULL while a,c's next is b)

Note that, the first result does not prevent you from getting a correct result, as long as you record the length of the original list and know where the mid point is, and stop checking at mid point.

However, the code will have Time Limit Exceed error if you build a list like 1, though your answer is right. This is really misleading.

discussion_posts.name: user3353xR
discussion_posts.content: A bit confused with this task, what do you actually pass as a parameter while testing in your IDE? The input parameter, head, is a ListNode, the constructor of which is a an integer. In the example use cases the input is an array of integers (obviously meant to represent the entire List) .. So what do you do when you test in your own environment, do you build the LinkedList before the method, and truly pass the head node, or what?
